comments.p: NOTE: The courses shown below include a high level of learning support for each student. This high level of support is provided to help students build success at each step in their course. To help build this success students enrolling initially in ECON 2301 will be enrolled in ECON 1303 (self-paced/online) with the same section number. This concurrent enrollment is required unless the student has completed ECON 1303 in a previous semester or is enrolling in a Distance Learning section of ECON 2301.

The concurrent ECON 1303 course provides the student with the high level HelpLab support and provides the self-paced preparation ("prepare-as-you-go" course) for ECON 2301. The enhanced HelpLab support includes personal one-to-one tutoring, group test review sessions, multimedia study materials and online practice tests along with personal assistance by telephone and e-mail.

ECON 1303 is a transferable credit course, is a Core Curriculum course and can be taken independently online (see Distance Learning section below) or, as indicated above, will be taken concurrently with ECON 2301.

The orientation for the concurrent ECON 1303 is part of the orientation for the ECON 2301 course carrying the same section number. If there are any questions, please come by the ECON HelpLab, Room M130, call 972-860-4169 or 972-860-4164, or e-mail Gus Herring at gHerring@dcccd.edu with a copy to Bob Smith at bSmith1@dcccd.edu.

comments.p: NOTE: If you are working toward obtaining the Accounting Clerk Certificate or the Accounting Assistant Certificate, you may take these courses even though you have not taken the Texas Success Initiative exam. Obtain a TSI waiver form online, or call 972-860-4160, for more information.

This program will allow you to obtain marketable job skills necessary for entry-level accounting positions. The courses in this program will give you an opportunity to acquire basic accounting, 10-key, spreadsheet, and word processing skills.
The following five courses must be completed to receive this certificate. Upon completion, you will have earned 16 college credits.
*You must be employed to enroll in ACNT 1380. If you are not employed, select a Business/Technical elective.

comments.p: NOTE: The courses shown below include a high level of learning support for each student. This high level of support is provided to help students build success at each step in their course. To help build this success students enrolling initially in ECON 2301 will be enrolled in ECON 1303 (self-paced/online) with the same section number. This concurrent enrollment is required unless the student has completed ECON 1303 in a previous semester or is enrolling in a Distance Learning section of ECON 2301.

The concurrent ECON 1303 course provides the student with the high level HelpLab support and provides the self-paced preparation ("prepare-as-you-go" course) for ECON 2301. The enhanced HelpLab support includes personal one-to-one tutoring, group test review sessions, multimedia study materials and online practice tests along with personal assistance by telephone and e-mail.

ECON 1303 is a transferable credit course, is a Core Curriculum course and can be taken independently online (see Distance Learning section below) or, as indicated above, will be taken concurrently with ECON 2301.

The orientation for the concurrent ECON 1303 is part of the orientation for the ECON 2301 course carrying the same section number. If there are any questions, please come by the ECON HelpLab, Room M130, call 972-860-4169 or 972-860-4164, or e-mail Gus Herring at gHerring@dcccd.edu with a copy to Bob Smith at bSmith1@dcccd.edu.

subject.name: Biology
subject.comments: NOTE: Meeting course prerequisites is very important to your success in science courses. Before registering, check the Catalog online or call the division office for prerequisite information.

topic.name: Majors Biology
topic.comments: NOTE: Biology 1406 and 1407 are courses for students majoring and/or minoring in biology or related disciplines. It is recommended that students have recently had either high school biology or Biology 1408 or 1409. It is also recommended that students have recently had high school chemistry or Chemistry 1405 before taking this course.

topic.name: Non-Majors Biology
topic.comments: NOTE: Biology 1408 and 1409 are courses for non-majors. Non-science majors and returning students with limited biology background may take either course in preparation for their first biology course for majors. There are no prerequisites.

course.title: Biol for Non-Science Majors I
course.comments: Content includes biology in the modern world, DNA, genetics and the cell.

Online orientation is also available. Lectures, labs, most assignments, tests and quizzes are online, however, a midterm exam, lab practicals 1 & 2, and the final exam will be taken in the Testing Center or a prearranged alternate site.

comments.p: NOTE: If you are working toward obtaining the Accounting Clerk Certificate or the Accounting Assistant Certificate, you may take these courses even though you have not taken the Texas Success Initiative exam. Obtain a TSI waiver form online, or call 972-860-4160, for more information.

This program will allow you to obtain marketable job skills necessary for entry-level accounting positions. The courses in this program will give you an opportunity to acquire basic accounting, 10-key, spreadsheet, and word processing skills.
The following five courses must be completed to receive this certificate. Upon completion, you will have earned 16 college credits.
*You must be employed to enroll in ACNT 1380. If you are not employed, select a Business/Technical elective.

comments.p: NOTE: The courses shown below include a high level of learning support for each student. This high level of support is provided to help students build success at each step in their course. To help build this success students enrolling initially in ECON 2301 will be enrolled in ECON 1303 (self-paced/online) with the same section number. This concurrent enrollment is required unless the student has completed ECON 1303 in a previous semester or is enrolling in a Distance Learning section of ECON 2301.

The concurrent ECON 1303 course provides the student with the high level HelpLab support and provides the self-paced preparation ("prepare-as-you-go" course) for ECON 2301. The enhanced HelpLab support includes personal one-to-one tutoring, group test review sessions, multimedia study materials and online practice tests along with personal assistance by telephone and e-mail.

ECON 1303 is a transferable credit course, is a Core Curriculum course and can be taken independently online (see Distance Learning section below) or, as indicated above, will be taken concurrently with ECON 2301.

The orientation for the concurrent ECON 1303 is part of the orientation for the ECON 2301 course carrying the same section number. If there are any questions, please come by the ECON HelpLab, Room M130, call 972-860-4169 or 972-860-4164, or e-mail Gus Herring at gHerring@dcccd.edu with a copy to Bob Smith at bSmith1@dcccd.edu.

course.title: Digital Art I
course.comments: New Genres in Digital Art: Seattle artist Cat Clifford will lead a seminar in New Genres. Using digital video, sound and hand-drawn animation each student will thoroughly document a space of their choosing. These explorations will result in a video portrait of the student's chosen space. Students will be encouraged to explore innovative and experimental approaches to these nontraditional media and processes.

This program will allow you to obtain marketable job skills necessary for entry-level accounting positions. The courses in this program will give you an opportunity to acquire basic accounting, 10-key, spreadsheet, and word processing skills.
The following five courses must be completed to receive this certificate. Upon completion, you will have earned 16 college credits.

comments.p: NOTE: The courses shown below include a high level of learning support for each student. This high level of support is provided to help students build success at each step in their course. To help build this success students enrolling initially in ECON 2301 will be enrolled in ECON 1303 (self-paced/online) with the same section number. This concurrent enrollment is required unless the student has completed ECON 1303 in a previous semester or is enrolling in a Distance Learning section of ECON 2301.

The concurrent ECON 1303 course provides the student with the high level HelpLab support and provides the self-paced preparation ("prepare-as-you-go" course) for ECON 2301. The enhanced HelpLab support includes personal one-to-one tutoring, group test review sessions, multimedia study materials and online practice tests along with personal assistance by telephone and e-mail.

ECON 1303 is a transferable credit course, is a Core Curriculum course and can be taken independently online (see Distance Learning section below) or, as indicated above, will be taken concurrently with ECON 2301.

The orientation for the concurrent ECON 1303 is part of the orientation for the ECON 2301 course carrying the same section number. If there are any questions, please come by the ECON HelpLab, Room M130, call 972-860-4169 or 972-860-4164, or e-mail Gus Herring at gHerring@dcccd.edu with a copy to Bob Smith at bSmith1@dcccd.edu.

comments.p: NOTE: If you are working toward obtaining the Accounting Clerk Certificate or the Accounting Assistant Certificate, you may take these courses even though you have not taken the Texas Success Initiative exam. Obtain a TSI waiver form online, or call 972-860-4160, for more information.

This program will allow you to obtain marketable job skills necessary for entry-level accounting positions. The courses in this program will give you an opportunity to acquire basic accounting, 10-key, spreadsheet, and word processing skills.
The following five courses must be completed to receive this certificate. Upon completion, you will have earned 16 college credits.
*You must be employed to enroll in ACNT 1380. If you are not employed, select a Business/Technical elective.

subject.name: Biology
subject.comments: NOTE: Meeting course prerequisites is very important to your success in science courses. Before registering, check the Catalog online or call the division office for prerequisite information.

topic.name: Majors Biology
topic.comments: NOTE: Biology 1406 and 1407 are courses for students majoring and/or minoring in biology or related disciplines. It is recommended that students have recently had either high school biology or Biology 1408 or 1409. It is also recommended that students have recently had high school chemistry or Chemistry 1405 before taking this course.

topic.name: Non-Majors Biology
topic.comments: NOTE: Biology 1408 and 1409 are courses for non-majors. Non-science majors and returning students with limited biology background may take either course in preparation for their first biology course for majors. There are no prerequisites.

course.title: Biol for Non-Science Majors I
course.comments: Students are required to take 3 tests (up to 6 hrs) at the testing center outside of a regularly scheduled class time.

course.title: Biol for Non-Science Majors I
course.comments: Content includes biology in the modern world, DNA, genetics and the cell.

course.title: Biol for Non-Science Majors I

course.title: Digital Art I
course.comments: New Genres in Digital Art: Seattle artist Cat Clifford will lead a seminar in New Genres. Using digital video, sound and hand-drawn animation each student will thoroughly document a space of their choosing. These explorations will result in a video portrait of the student's chosen space. Students will be encouraged to explore innovative and experimental approaches to these nontraditional media and processes.

subject.name: Senior Adult Education Program
subject.comments: All courses listed under Senior Adult Education Program have been planned for adults who are 50 years or older. For information and personal assistance with registration, please call DeBorah Whaley- Stephenson at 972-860-4807 or Janice Groeneman at 972-860-4698. The Senior Adult Education offices are located in Building M, in rooms M203 and M211A. Are you eligible for FREE tuition? If you are 65 years or older and reside in Dallas County (or own property in Dallas County subject to ad valorem taxation), tuition for credit classes is waived for up to six credit hours per semester.

course.title: Computer Literacy/Basic Skills
course.comments: POFI 1104-2205 is designed for the novice who has little or no experience with computers. In this computer literacy course you will practice using the mouse, learn about the components of the computer, including the keyboard and perform rudimentary tasks. After completing this course, you will be ready to enroll in Introduction to Computers/Windows XP.

course.title: Google for Genealogists II
course.comments: POFI 1104-2203 is a four-session course in which students learn the Google spreadsheet for chronology reports and Google translate for translating documents in a foreign language. You also will learn how to use Google groups for finding overlooked genealogical information and use more than 4,500 indexed URLs for genealogical research. Recommended prerequisite: Google for Genealogists Part II.

course.title: Digital Cameras
course.comments: POFI 1104-2006 is a six-session course that covers the basic operation and features of a digital camera. Students will learn the process of transferring photos to the computer, how to take pictures with an eye for computer enhancement, and how to use photos in e-mails and Web pages. Storage and retrieval of digital photos will be reviewed.

course.title: Internet Part I
course.comments: POFI 1104-2204 is a six-session beginning Internet course using Microsoft Internet Explorer, with reference to SBC/Yahoo and AOL. This course will emphasize basic e-mail functions plus attachments, searches using Google and other search engines, addressing Web pages, using instant messenger and discussion groups. You will learn to shop and purchase online and perform other activities at popular Web sites. Recommended prerequisite: Windows XP

course.title: Photoshop Elements Part I
course.comments: POFI 1104-2207 is a six-session course to help you import, organize and enhance your photos. Using the Photoshop Elements software you will develop skills in cropping, rotating, resizing, straightening and red eye removal. Recommended prerequisites: Windows XP and Beginning Internet.

course.title: Windows Xp/Com Basic
course.comments: POFI 1204 Introduction to Computers and Windows XP focuses on computer literacy and terminology of the Microsoft Windows XP operating system. Components of personal computers, hardware and software will be taught as well as menu bars, toolbars and shortcuts. You will learn to name, save, locate and print files and also use the word processing program to create, edit and format files.

course.title: Windows XP/Com Basic
course.comments: POFI 1204 Introduction to Computers and Windows XP focuses on computer literacy and terminology of the Microsoft Windows XP operating system. Components of personal computers, hardware and software will be taught as well as menu bars, toolbars and shortcuts. You will learn to name, save, locate and print files and also use the word processing program to create, edit and format files.

course.title: Word 2003 Part I
course.comments: POFI 1104-2202 is a six-session beginning Word class and will emphasize the basics of Microsoft's word processing program. It includes creating and editing Word documents; naming, saving and printing documents, menu, toolbars and shortcuts; formatting, cutting, copying and pasting text, margins and indents; and inserting graphics and text from other documents and applications. Recommended prerequisite: Windows XP

course.title: Conditioning Exercise
course.comments: This beginning conditioning course for students 50 and older will incorporate a variety of exercises to improve cardiovascular endurance, muscular strength, endurance and flexibility. Cardiovascular walking, rhythmic activities and weight training using small free weights and tubing also are included. Accommodation will be made for different levels of fitness.

course.title: Int Lifetime Sports Activities
course.comments: This intermediate conditioning course for students 50 and older will incorporate a variety of exercises to improve cardiovascular endurance, muscular strength, endurance and flexibility. Cardiovascular walking, rhythmic activities and weight training using small free weights and tubing are included. Accommodations will be made for different levels of fitness.

group.comments: This course, designed for students 50 and older, offers activities to improve cardiovascular endurance, muscular strength and endurance, flexibility, agility and balance. It includes low-impact aerobics, circuits and walking and will incorporate small hand weights and resistance tubing. Accommodation will be made for different levels of fitness.

comments.p: NOTE: The courses shown below include a high level of learning support for each student. This high level of support is provided to help students build success at each step in their course. To help build this success students enrolling initially in ECON 2301 will be enrolled in ECON 1303 (self-paced/online) with the same section number. This concurrent enrollment is required unless the student has completed ECON 1303 in a previous semester or is enrolling in a Distance Learning section of ECON 2301.

The concurrent ECON 1303 course provides the student with the high level HelpLab support and provides the self-paced preparation ("prepare-as-you-go" course) for ECON 2301. The enhanced HelpLab support includes personal one-to-one tutoring, group test review sessions, multimedia study materials and online practice tests along with personal assistance by telephone and e-mail.

ECON 1303 is a transferable credit course, is a Core Curriculum course and can be taken independently online (see Distance Learning section below) or, as indicated above, will be taken concurrently with ECON 2301.

The orientation for the concurrent ECON 1303 is part of the orientation for the ECON 2301 course carrying the same section number. If there are any questions, please come by the ECON HelpLab, Room M130, call 972-860-4169 or 972-860-4164, or e-mail Gus Herring at gHerring@dcccd.edu with a copy to Bob Smith at bSmith1@dcccd.edu.

comments.p: NOTE: If you are working toward obtaining the Accounting Clerk Certificate or the Accounting Assistant Certificate, you may take these courses even though you have not taken the Texas Success Initiative exam. Obtain a TSI waiver form online, or call 972-860-4160, for more information.

This program will allow you to obtain marketable job skills necessary for entry-level accounting positions. The courses in this program will give you an opportunity to acquire basic accounting, 10-key, spreadsheet, and word processing skills.
The following five courses must be completed to receive this certificate. Upon completion, you will have earned 16 college credits.
*You must be employed to enroll in ACNT 1380. If you are not employed, select a Business/Technical elective.

course.title: Prin Acct I

To complete the orientation, go to http://ecampus.dcccd.edu and follow the login procedures to access the course. Use your seven-digit student I.D. number as both the username and password. course.title: Painting I
course.comments: This 11-day Painting Workshop includes two and a half days with the modern master painter John Walker, professor of Boston University graduate painting program. With his art lectures and individual/group painting critiques, students will explore new ways of seeing and thinking about painting.

subject.comments: NOTE: Meeting course prerequisites is very important to your success in science courses. Before registering, check the Catalog online or call the division office for prerequisite information.

topic.name: Anatomy & Physiology for Nursing Majors
topic.comments: NOTE: Enrollment into SCIT 1407 will require an appropriate reading and writing score on one of the assessment instruments (THEA/TASP, etc.) taken within the last two years. If your reading or writing score is below the minimum cutoff, you will be advised to enroll into an alternative biology course, such as BIOL 1408 or DIRS 9170. SCIT 1407 is a prerequisite for the Nursing Program.

topic.name: Majors Biology
topic.comments: NOTE: Biology 1406 and 1407 are courses for students majoring and/or minoring in biology or related disciplines. It is recommended that students have recently had either high school biology or Biology 1408 or 1409. It is also recommended that students have recently had high school chemistry or Chemistry 1405 before taking this course.

topic.name: Non-Majors Biology
topic.comments: NOTE: Biology 1408 and 1409 are courses for non-majors. Non-science majors and returning students with limited biology background may take either course in preparation for their first biology course for majors. There are no prerequisites.

course.title: Biol for Non-Science Majors I
course.comments: Content includes biology in the modern world, DNA, genetics and the cell. The recommended on-campus orientation will be offered July 9 at 7:00 PM in Room K121. Online orientation is also available. Lectures, labs, most assignments, tests and quizzes are online, however, a midterm exam, lab practicals 1 and 2 and the final exam will be taken in the Testing Center or a prearranged alternate site.

comments.p: NOTE: The courses shown below include a high level of learning support for each student. This high level of support is provided to help students build success at each step in their course. To help build this success students enrolling initially in ECON 2301 will be enrolled in ECON 1303 (self-paced/online) with the same section number. This concurrent enrollment is required unless the student has completed ECON 1303 in a previous semester or is enrolling in a Distance Learning section of ECON 2301.

The concurrent ECON 1303 course provides the student with the high level HelpLab support and provides the self-paced preparation ("prepare-as-you-go" course) for ECON 2301. The enhanced HelpLab support includes personal one-to-one tutoring, group test review sessions, multimedia study materials and online practice tests along with personal assistance by telephone and e-mail.

ECON 1303 is a transferable credit course, is a Core Curriculum course and can be taken independently online (see Distance Learning section below) or, as indicated above, will be taken concurrently with ECON 2301.

The orientation for the concurrent ECON 1303 is part of the orientation for the ECON 2301 course carrying the same section number. If there are any questions, please come by the ECON HelpLab, Room M130, call 972-860-4169 or 972-860-4164, or e-mail Gus Herring at gHerring@dcccd.edu with a copy to Bob Smith at bSmith1@dcccd.edu.

course.title: Learning Framework
course.comments: HDEV 1300-2001 will help students develop skills that will support their success in college. Topics include, but are not limited to: motivation and self-discipline, time management, effective communication, test taking skills, reading/writing techniques, note taking, and the development of critical thinking skills.

course.title: Painting I
course.comments: This 11-day Painting Workshop includes two and a half days with the modern master painter John Walker, professor of Boston University graduate painting program. With his art lectures and individual/group painting critiques, students will explore new ways of seeing and thinking about painting.

course.title: Painting II
course.comments: This 11-day Painting Workshop includes two and a half days with the modern master painter John Walker, professor of Boston University graduate painting program. With his art lectures and individual/group painting critiques, students will explore new ways of seeing and thinking about painting.

course.title: Beg Self Defense
course.comments: The beginning self defense course utilizes the Northern and Southern styles of Shaolin-Kung-Fu method to teach basic self defense techniques. Both mental and physical aspects of the arts are stressed. Uniform required and will be discussed at first class.

course.title: Int Physical Fitness
course.comments: It is highly recommended that a student complete PHED 1164 prior to enrollment in the intermediate physical fitness course. This course offers continuation of a total fitness package including physical fitness assessment with computer printout, weight training and wellness concepts.

subject.name: Senior Adult Education Program
subject.comments: All courses listed under Senior Adult Education Program have been planned for adults who are 50 years or older. For information and personal assistance with registration, please call DeBorah Whaley- Stephenson at 972-860-4807 or Janice Groeneman at 972-860-4698. The Senior Adult Education offices are located in Building M, in rooms M203 and M211A. Are you eligible for FREE tuition? If you are 65 years or older and reside in Dallas County (or own property in Dallas County subject to ad valorem taxation), tuition for credit classes is waived for up to six credit hours per semester.

course.title: Internet Part 1
course.comments: POFI 1104-2201 is a six-session beginning Internet course using Microsoft Internet Explorer, with reference to SBC/Yahoo and AOL. This course will emphasize basic e-mail functions plus attachments, searches using Google and other search engines, addressing Web pages, using instant messenger and discussion groups. You will learn to shop and purchase online and perform other activities of popular Web sites. Recommended prerequisite: Windows XP.
